text: Applications
ACE 1-1

a. Miki tosses a coin 50 times, and the coin shows heads 28 times. What fraction of the 50 tosses is heads? What percent is this?

b. Suppose the coin is fair and Miki tosses it 500 times. About how many times can she expect it to show heads? Explain your reasoning.

a. 28/50 = 14/25, or 56%

b. It should come up heads about 250 times, or half of 500. It will most likely not be exactly 250 heads in 500 tosses, but it is unlikely to be far from 250 heads.
ACE 1-2

Suppose Kaleb tosses a coin to determine his screen time each day. He starts on his 12th birthday and continues until his 18th birthday. Kaleb gets 2 hours of screen time if the coin toss results in heads. About how many times would you expect him to get 2 hours a day?

He tosses each day for about 6 years. 6 × 365 days = 2,190 days (2,191 days; some students might add a day or two for leap years) for which Kaleb will toss a coin. You would expect him to toss heads and have screen time 2 hours a day about half of those days, or about 1,095 days.
ACE 1-3
Scarlett tosses a coin five days in a row and gets tails every time. Do you think there is something wrong with the coin? How can you find out?

With only five trials, you cannot be certain. Scarlett should toss the coin many more times if he wants to find out whether or not the coin is fair. In fact, the probability of five consecutive heads is 1/32 ≈ 3%.
ACE 1-4
Len tosses a coin three times. The coin shows heads every time. What are the chances the coin shows tails on the next toss? Explain.

The chances are 1/2, or 50%. If a coin turns up heads three times in a row, it is not more likely to turn up tails the next time, nor is it more likely to be heads again. This can be confusing for students because they expect the average to be about 50% in the short run. Experimental results are about results in the long run.
ACE 1-5
Is it possible to toss a coin 20 times and have it land heads-up 20 times? Is this likely to happen? Explain.

It is possible but unlikely. Each time a coin is tossed, it can land heads up, so 20 heads in a row is possible. However, there are many more possible combinations of 20 coin tosses that are not all heads, so 20 heads is very unlikely. The chance of getting 20 heads in a row is about 0.000001, that is, about 1 chance in a million.
ACE 1-6

Nora tosses a paper cup once each day to determine her breakfast.

a. How many times do you expect the cup to land on its side? On one of its ends?

b. If the cup lands on an end Nora gets to have Cocoa Blast cereal for breakfast. How many times do you expect Nora to eat Cocoa Blast in a month? In a year? Explain.

a. Answers will vary based on the experiments conducted in class. A group of students that found 20 ends in the 50 tosses should argue for a number about 7 times as large (146 ends and 219 sides in a year, 50 × 7 = 350 < 365).

b. Answers will vary based on the experiments conducted in class. In the example from ACE 6a, 40% of the tosses resulted in ends, so this should happen about 12 times a month (40% of 30), or 146 times a year (40% of 365).
ACE 1-7
Moni tosses a pawn from her chess set five times. It lands on its base four times and on its side only once.

Andre tosses the same pawn 100 times. It lands on its base 28 times and on its side 72 times. Based on their data, if you toss the pawn one more time, is it more likely to land on its base or its side? Explain.
The pawn is more likely to land on its side, because it is better to base a prediction on 100 tosses than on 5 tosses. It gives you even more information if you combine the data.
ACE 1-8

Blake flips a small paper cup 50 times and a large paper cup 30 times. He wants to use this to decide whether he will eat Cocoa Blast or Health Nut Flakes cereal for breakfast. The table below displays the results of his experiments.

a. Write the experimental probability: P(small cup landing on side) =

b. Write the experimental probability: P(large cup landing on side) =

c. If Blake is going to base his decision for Cocoa Blast cereal on the cup landing on its side, should he use the small cup or the large cup to determine his breakfast each morning? Explain

c. Blake should use the small cup and eat Cocoa Blast when it lands on its side. This is because the large cup landed on its side about 73% of the time in his experiments while the small cup landed on its side 78% of the time. Some students may argue that the number of trials was not sufficiently large with the large cup and so the probabilities may be even closer than they appear.
ACE 1-9

Kate finds a way to pick breakfast. She places one blue marble and one red marble in each of two bags. She says that each morning she can choose one marble from each bag. If the marbles are the same color, she eats Cocoa Blast. If not, she eats Health Nut Flakes. Explain how selecting one marble from each of the two bags and tossing two coins are similar.
Red and blue are like heads and tails. Each bag is like a coin. Red and blue are equally likely in each bag, just as heads and tails are on each coin.
ACE 1-10

Adsila and Adahy have to decide who will take out the garbage. Adahy suggests they toss two coins. He says that if at least one head comes up, Adsila takes out the garbage. If no heads come up, Adahy takes out the garbage. Should Adsila agree to Adahy’s proposal? Explain why or why not.
Adsila should not agree. The probability of getting at least one head is 75%. Students can determine this by considering the possibilities or by referring to their data from Problem 1.2.
For ACE 11–15, decide whether the possible results are equally likely. Explain.
ACE 1-11

Action: Your phone rings at 9:00 p.m.

Possible Result: The caller is your best friend, the caller is a relative, or the caller is someone else.
The results are probably not equally likely. It is more likely that a friend or family member would call at 9:00 p.m. than someone else.
ACE 1-12

Action: You check the temperature at your home tomorrow morning.

Possible Result: The temperature is 30°F or above, or the temperature is below 30°F.
Depending on the season, the results are probably not equally likely. Students should have a good idea of whether the local temperature is more likely to be under or above 30°F.
ACE 1-13
Action: You spin the pointer once.
Possible Result: The pointer lands on yellow, the pointer lands on red, or the pointer lands on blue.

The results are not equally likely. The spinner landing on red is more likely than the spinner landing on yellow or on blue, because the red takes up 1/2 of the circle’s area, whereas the yellow and blue only take up 1/4 of the circle’s area. Students may want to experiment with this spinner or analyze the spinner with their angle ruler.
ACE 1-14

Action: You find out how many car accidents occurred in your city or town yesterday.

Possible Result: There were fewer than five accidents, there were exactly five accidents, or there were more than five accidents.

The results are probably not equally likely, as the size and layout of the town or city would affect the number of accidents. (To find out for your city, you would need to know the average number of accidents that occur on a given day. The average might be different for a Monday than a Saturday.)
ACE 1-15

Action: You choose a card from a deck of 60 cards that has 15 red cards, 15 yellow cards, 15 blue cards, and 15 purple cards.

Possible Result: The card is red, the card is yellow, the card is blue, or the card is purple.
The results are equally likely. Each deck of cards contains exactly 15 red cards, 15 yellow cards, 15 blue cards, and 15 purple cards. Thus, the chances of drawing any one particular color are 1/4.
For Exercises 16–17, first list all the possible results for each action. Then decide whether the results are equally likely.
ACE 1-16
You choose a block from a bag containing one red block, three blue blocks, and one green block.

There are three possible results—choosing a red block, a blue block, or a green block. The results are not equally likely. There are more blue blocks in the bag, so the chances of drawing a blue block are greater than the chances of drawing a red or green block.
ACE 1-17
You try to steal second base during a baseball game.

There are two possible results—you succeed in stealing second base, or you are out. These results are probably not equally likely. Their chances depend on the person’s skill and experience playing baseball and stealing bases.
Connections
ACE 1-18

For ACE 18a–f, give an example of a result that would have a probability near the percent given.

a. 0%

b. 25%

c. 50%

d. 75%

e. 80%

f. 100%

a. Example Answer: It will be 250°F in Texas on the first day of January.

b. Example Answer: You guess the right answer on a multiple-choice question with four options.

c. Example Answer: A quarter will land heads up when it is tossed.

d. Example Answer: It will snow during a week of winter in New Hampshire.

e. Example Answer: When you choose a letter at random from the letters A, B, C, D, and F, you choose a consonant.

f. Example Answer: The sun will set tonight.
ACE 1-19
Colby rolls a number cube 50 times. She records the result of each roll and organizes her data in the table below.

a. What fraction of the rolls are 2s? What percent is this?

b. What fraction of the rolls are odd numbers? What percent is this?

c. What percent of the rolls is greater than 3?

d. Suppose Colby rolls the number cube 100 times. About how many times can she expect to roll a 2? Explain.

e. If Colby rolls the number cube 1,000 times, about how many times can she expect to roll an odd number? Explain.

a. 9/50; 18%

b. 23/50, 46%

c. 29/50; 58%

d. Answers will vary. Possible answers: 16 (the result of 100 roles ÷ 6 possibilities); students may double the results from the given table and answer “18 times.”

e. She can expect about 500 odd numbers, since odd and even are equally likely. Students may scale the results from this table and respond “460 times.”
ACE 1-20
Find a fraction between each pair of fractions.

a. Answers will vary.

Possible answers: 1/5, 9/50, 1/4

b. Answers will vary.

Possible Answers: 12/40, 13/40, 14/40
For ACE 21-23 use the following bar graph.
ACE 1-21

Multiple Choice:

Suppose 41,642 people moved. About how many of those people moved for family-related reasons?

A. 28

B. 11,000

C. 21,000

D. 31,000
B. 11,000
ACE 1-22

Multiple Choice:

What ratio of the people represented in the graph moved for reasons other than work-related, housing-related, or family-related reasons?

A. 6/10

B. 52/100

C. 94/100

D. 6/100
D. 6/100
ACE 1-23

Multiple Choice:

Suppose 41,642 people moved. About how many moved for housing-related reasons?

A. 52

B. 11,000

C. 21,000

D. 31,000
C. 21,000
ACE 1-24

Suppose you write all the factors of 42 on pieces of paper and put them in a bag. You shake the bag. Then, you choose one piece of paper from the bag. Find the experimental probability of choosing the following.

a. An even number

b. A prime number

a. Answers will vary. Students should describe putting all the factors, 1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 14, 21, and 42, on pieces of paper, then repeating several trials to make the experiment.

Sample for 20 trials:

1, 3, 21, 42, 2, 7, 6, 2, 42, 21, 3, 3, 6, 21, 7, 7, 14, 42, 1, 42, and 21. This trial leads to a probability of 9/20 even factors.

Note: The theoretical probability is 1/2.

b. Answers will vary. Using the sample data from ACE 24a, the probability for prime factors is 8/20.

Note: The theoretical probability is 3/8.
ACE 1-25

Weather forecasters often use percents to give probabilities in their forecasts. For example, a forecaster might say that there is a 50% chance of rain tomorrow. For the following forecasts, change the fractional probabilities to percents.

a. The probability that it will rain tomorrow is 2/5.

b. The probability it will snow Monday is 3/10.

c. The probability it will be cloudy this weekend is 3/5.

a. 40%, since 2/5 = 40/100, or since 2 ÷ 5 = 0.40

b. 30%, since 3/10 =30/100, or since 3 ÷ 10 = 0.30

c. 60%, since 3/5 = 60/100, or since 3 ÷ 5 = 0.60
ACE 1-26
Find the solution to each proportion.

a. x = 10

b. x = 12

c. x = 22.5

d. x = 4

e. x = 20

f. x = 210
For ACE 27-30, use the following graph.
ACE 1-27
Is a tornado equally likely to occur in Arkansas and in Wyoming? Explain your reasoning.
No, a tornado is more likely to occur somewhere in Arkansas. (The average number of tornadoes in Arkansas is about 40 while the number is about 10 in wyoming.)
ACE 1-28
Is a tornado equally likely to occur in Florida and in Minnesota?
Yes, tornados are equally likely to occur in Florida and Minnesota.
ACE 1-29
Is a tornado equally likely to occur in Illinois and in Texas?
No, a tornado is more likely to occur somewhere in Texas.
ACE 1-30
Based on these data, is a person living in California more likely to experience a tornado than a person living in Massachusetts? Explain.

No. Although the data show that more tornadoes strike California than Massachusetts, this does not mean that a resident of California is more likely to experience a tornado than a resident in Massachusetts. For example, consider that Massachusetts is much smaller than California, and that many fewer people live in Massachusetts than in California.
ACE 1-31
Find a value that makes each equation or inequality correct.

a. 12

b. any number greater than 15

c. any number greater than 12

d. 1.5, or any number greater than 1.5

e. 9, or any number greater than 9

f. 28
Extensions
ACE 1-32

Monday is the first day Kaleb tosses a coin to determine his screen time. Kaleb gets 2 hours of screen time if the coin toss results in heads. During the first five days, he gets 2 hours a day of screen time only twice. One possible pattern of Kaleb's coin tosses is shown.
Find every way Kaleb can toss the coin during the week and get 2 hours a day of screen time only twice. Explain how you know that you found every possible way.

Possible explanation: I have organized my list in a way that helps me be sure I have all the possibilities. First, I put one H in the first position and moved the second H through the other four positions. Then I put the H in the second position and moved the other H into the third through the fifth positions. I continued this pattern until I had covered all the possibilities. I know I have not duplicated any because the first H changes position with each column.
ACE 1-33

Yolanda watches a carnival game in which a paper cup is tossed. It costs $1 to play the game. If the cup lands upright, the player receives $5. Otherwise, the player receives nothing. The cup is tossed 50 times. It lands on its side 32 times, upside down 13 times, and upright 5 times.

a. If Yolanda plays the game 10 times, about how many times can she expect to win? How many times can she expect to lose?

b. Do you expect her to have more or less money at the end of 10 games? Explain.

a. Since the cup lands upright 5 times out of 50, Yolanda can expect to win about 1 out of 10 times. She can expect to lose about 9 out of 10 times.

b. Less; Yolanda would have to spend $ 10 to play 10 times. You should expect her to win once, giving her $5, so she would have spent $5 more than she won. Of course, this is only a good guess about what to expect. She may actually lose more money or win money.
ACE 1-34

a. If you roll one number cube two times, what is the probability of getting a factor of 5 both times?

b. Suppose you roll two different number cubes. What is the probability of getting a factor of 5 on both cubes?

c. How do your answers to parts ACE 34a and ACE 34b compare? Explain why the answers have this relationship.

a. The factors of 5 are 5 and 1, so there is a 2 out of 6 or 1/3 chance on each roll of getting a factor of 5. The probability of getting a factor of 5 on two consecutive rolls is 1/9.

Note: Students may list all possible combinations, draw a model, collect experimental data, or, if they are beginning to see the connection to multiplying fractions, compute 1/3 × 1/3 = 1/9.

b. 4/36, or 1/9

c. The answers are the same; rolling the same number cube a second time is equivalent to rolling a second number cube. Each roll of a number cube is independent of other rolls.
